Overview

The Android SDK provided by Built.io Backend is available for both, the Android studio environment as well as the Eclipse environment. Let us quickly understand the process to install and initialize this SDK, as well as the additional features it provides.


Important Changes

Built.io Backend has depcreated the use of GroupMultiple. For a detailed explaination please read through this blog post.


Installation

To use this SDK on android platform, you will have to install the SDK according to the steps given below.

  • Download the Built.io android sdk.

  • The zip file contains the Built.io Backend SDK, the user interface kit and the starter kit. Extract the Built.io zip file at the desired location.

  • Eclipse

    1. Copy Built.io-xxx-javadoc, Built.io-xxx.jar, Built.io-xxx.jar.properties to your project's libs folder.

    2. Add jar refrences in the projects propeties --> Java Build Path --> Libraries tab.


  • Android Studio

    1. Copy Built.io-xxx.jar to your project's libs folder.

    2. Add dependency code in your build.gradle file. 

      dependencies {compile fileTree(dir: 'libs', include: ['*.jar'])}
  • Configure AndroidManifest.xml with permissions and receivers.

Basic structure

The structure followed by the SDK logically resembles the application structure on Built.io Backend. Once you are done with the basic setup explained in the Installation section, your Android SDK is ready, which you can then use to initialize different modules.
The initialization process for each module is explained below briefly.
  • BuiltApplication

    To initialize a BuiltApplication instance, use the 'application(Context context, String api_key)' method on the Built class and set the application's api key and context.

      //'blt5d4sample2633b' is dummy Application API key.
    BuiltApplication builtApplication = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
  • BuiltClass

    BuiltApplication can have multiple classes. Similarly, a BuiltApplication instance has a classWithUid method, which accepts the uid of the BuiltClass whose instance is to be created.

     // 'project' is a uid of a class on Built.io Backend.
    BuiltClass projectClass = builtApplication.classWithUid("project");
  • BuiltObject

    BuiltObject is an instance of a BuiltClass. A BuiltClass instance has two methods: 'object()' and 'object(String object_uid)' (which accepts an existing objectâ€™s uid to initialize a new object).

      BuiltObject projectObject = projectClass.object();
  • BuiltQuery

    BuiltQuery is used to retrieve objects of a class based on some conditions. BuiltClass instance has method query, which, when executed, would retrieve objects of that class with the specified conditions.

      BuiltQuery projectQuery = projectClass.query();
  • BuiltUpload

    The BuiltUpload is used to upload files. BuiltUpload can be accessed on the BuiltApplication instance, which has upload() and upload(String uid) methods.

      BuiltUpload upload = builtApplication.upload();


Cache Policies

The SDK supports caching. A set of cache policies are avaliable for use, which are listed below.

  • ONLY_NETWORK (Default)

    This is the default cache policy which will always get the data from a network call.

  • CACHE_ELSE_NETWORK

    This policy will try to first get the data from cache; on failure, it would make a network call.

  • NETWORK_ELSE_CACHE

    This policy will try to first make a network call; on failure, it would fetch the data from cache.

  • CACHE_THEN_NETWORK

    This policy would first get the data from cache. It will then make a network call to get the updated copy. Cache policy can be set for all queries or for a particular query instance.

    Cache policy can be set for all queries or perticular query instance.

     BuiltQuery.setGlobalCachePolicy(BuiltQuery.CachePolicy.CACHE_ELSE_NETWORK);
     
BuiltQuery projectQuery = Built.application(context,"blt5d4sample2633b").classWithUid('project').query();

projectQuery.setCachePolicy(Built.CachePolicy.CACHE_ELSE_NETWORK);

ACL - Access Control List

The SDK provides some additional features that may be helpful for users. These features are explained below.

  1. If you want to set permissions for BuiltObject, BuiltFile, BuiltInstallation, and BuiltRole, it can be done using the BuiltACL class.

    Let's say, you want to set read permission for BuiltFile for all users. You can do this by following the steps given below.

    1. Create an ACL object with the intended permission.

      2.     // 'blt5d4sample2633b' is a dummy Application API key
    BuiltApplication builtApplication = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
    BuiltACL acl = builtApplication.acl();
    acl.setPublicReadAccess(true); // set read permission for all.

    2. Create a BuiltUpload object and apply ACL to it.

      3.     BuiltUpload builtUpload = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b").upload() 
    builtUpload.setACL(acl);   //Set acl object.

Realtime Functionality

Several applications, such as chat, stock updates, alarm system, etc. require data to be fetched and pushed to and forth from the server in a matter of seconds.
To support these requirements, Built.io Backend provides realtime functionality. In this, a socket connection is established between the client and the server, which enhances the speed of communication between them.

  • Usage :

    To use realtime-based SDK, follow the steps given below.

      To use the realtime-based SDK, follow the steps given below.After Installation, create a BuiltApplication instance, which can be used for enabling realtime as shown below.

    • After the installation , create an BuiltApplication instance, which can be used for realtime enabling as shown below.

       
        // If class level implementation is present of RealTimeCallback interface.
        public class MainActivity implements BuiltRealTimeCallback{

            // enableRealtime function on execution initiates socket connection.
            // 'blt5d4sample2633b' is dummy Application API key.
            BuiltApplication builtApplication  = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
            builtApplication.enableRealTime(context);

            /*Interface will add three functions as a connection handler.*/
        }

        //method-level implementation of RealTimeCallback interface[Optional].
        BuiltApplication builtApplication = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
        builtApplication.enableRealTime(new BuiltRealTimeCallback() { .... });
  • Event Listener:

    Built.io Backend uses events to notify the users when a particular action is performed. To listen to these events, we must first setup event listeners. The SDK provides several handy functions that help you manege the realtime functionality better. These functions are explained below in detail.

    • on

      This function is available in BuiltApplication, BuiltClass, BuiltObject, BuiltUser and BuiltUpload classes. It takes two arguments: the event which we would like to listen to, and the callback to be invoked when the event is triggered. Below is an example where we set up a listener on an instance. Setting up a listener on an instance requires read permission on it. (Refer actual documentation for more detailed explaination).

        
        // 'blt5d4sample2633b' is a dummy Application API key
        // 'classWithUid("class_uid") returns an 'BuiltClass' instance.
        BuiltApplication builtApplication = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
        BuiltClass projectClass = builtApplication.classWithUid("project");
        BuiltObject projectObject = projectClass.object();

        projectObject.on(Built.EventType.CREATE, new BuiltOnEventCallback() {
            @Override
            public void onReceive(Object object, BuiltError error) {
                if (error == null) {
                    //receive block which get call while listening a particular event happened. 
                    BuiltObject builtObj = (BuiltObject) object;
                } else {
                    //More details if error occured while listening event.
                }
            }
        });
    • off

      As the name suggests, this method is used to stop a user from listening to event notifications.

        
        // 'blt5d4sample2633b' is a dummy Application API key
        // 'classWithUid("class_uid") returns an 'BuiltClass' instance.
        BuiltApplication builtApplication = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
        BuiltClass projectClass = builtApplication.classWithUid("project");
        BuiltObject projectObject = projectClass.object();

        //Listening on new object creation in perticular class.
        projectObject.on(Built.EventType.CREATE, new BuiltOnEventCallback() { .... }
        });

        //Listening on object updation in perticular class.
        projectObject.on(Built.EventType.UPDATE, new BuiltOnEventCallback() { .... }
        });

        projectObject.off(Built.EventType.UPDATE, new BuiltOffEventCallback() {
            @Override
            public void onCompletion(BuiltConstant.ResponseType resType, BuiltError error){
                if (error == null) {
                    //success block.
                } else {
                    //More details if error occured while stopping listen on event.
                }
            }
        });
    • broadcast

      Built.io Backend allows you to broadcast messages that could be listened by others by setting up listeners for it. Broadcast method should be used to broadcast messages, and is available on BuiltApplication, BuiltClass, BuiltObject, BuiltUser and BuiltUpload instances. Update permission is required on the resource to be able to broadbast a message. The example given below demonstrates the syntax.

        
        // 'blt5d4sample2633b' is a dummy Application API key
        // 'classWithUid("class_uid") returns an 'BuiltClass' instance.
        BuiltApplication builtApplication = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
        BuiltClass projectClass = builtApplication.classWithUid("project");
        BuiltObject projectObject = projectClass.object("blt0ae4df463e93f6f5");

        //Listening on broadcast.
        projectObject.on(Built.EventType.BROADCAST, new BuiltOnEventCallback() { .... }
        });

        //Broadcasting message.
        projectObject.broadcast("Hi...!!!", new BuiltBroadCastCallback() {
            @Override
            public void onCompletion(BuiltConstant.ResponseType resType, BuiltError error){
                    if (error == null) {
                    //success block.
                    } else {
                    //More details if error occured while broadcasting.
                    }
            }
        });
    • presence

      This feature helps you determine if a certain application user is currently online or offline. It stores the "last seen" timestamp of the user, which is especially useful for chat applications. Additionally, it allows you to store a "status message" for your profile. Here is a list of some handy functions that will help you use the presence feature better.

      • Presence Operations

        1. To get the logged-in user's presence details, a combination of two methods will be used, i.e., getCurrentUser() on BuiltApplication class and getPresence() on BuiltUser, which returns a BuiltPresence instance. If the user wants to fetch the latest presence, then getPresence(BuiltResultCallBack) method will make this task easier (Refer to the actual documentation for details about presence module).

           
   BuiltUser userObject = builtApplication.getCurrentUser();
   BuiltPresence presenceObject = userObject.getPresence();
   presenceObject.setPrivacyStatus(BuiltPresence.PrivacyType.PUBLIC);

   presenceObject.save(new BuiltResultCallBack() {
       @Override
       public void onCompletion(BuiltConstant.ResponseType resType, BuiltError error) {
           if (error == null) {
               //success block.
           } else {
               //More details if error occured while saving presence.
           }
       }
   });

        2. To get the presence details of some other application user, the SDK provides getPresence(BuiltResultCallBack) method on BuiltUser instance. The below given example demonstrates the syntax.

           
   // 'blt5d4sample2633b' is a dummy Application API key
   BuiltApplication builtApplication = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
   BuiltUser userObject = builtApplication.user("bltba9a44506dd9e741");

   userObject.getPresence(new BuiltResultCallBack() {
       @Override
       public void onCompletion(BuiltConstant.ResponseType resType, BuiltError error){
           if (error == null) {
               //success block.
           } else {
               //More details if error occured while fetching presence.
           }
       }
   });
   /*You would be able access the presence details of a user only if the user has allowed his/her presence details to be publicly visible or has shared it with you, by adding you in the whitelist.*/
      • Request Presence

        In some chat applications, you may want to put a functionality that allows you to access other users' presece details by requesting access. We provide a similar functionality with requestPresence function. You can request a certain user to access his presence. The example below demonstrates the syntax.

          
   // 'blt5d4sample2633b' is a dummy Application API key
   BuiltApplication builtApplication = Built.application(context, "blt5d4sample2633b");
   BuiltUser userObject = builtApplication.user("bltba9a44506dd9e741");

   userObject.requestPresence(new BuiltResultCallBack() {
   
     @Override
     public void onCompletion(BuiltConstant.ResponseType type, BuiltError error){
         if (error == null) {
         //success block.
         } else {
         //More details if error occured while requesting presence.
         }
     }
   });
